I'm 65 years old and the room started spinning suddenly about 90 minutes ago while
I was eating dinner. It came on all at once — severe rotational vertigo, nausea, I
vomited twice. I also feel a bit unsteady when I try to walk, like I'm listing to
the right. I've had BPPV — benign positional vertigo — for about 8 years and my ENT
has treated it multiple times. This feels like a really bad BPPV episode. Should I
just do the Epley maneuver at home or do I need to be seen?

You should **be seen urgently today—ideally call 911 or go to the Emergency Department now**, rather than treating this as routine BPPV at home.

Even though you’ve had BPPV before, **your age (65) + sudden severe continuous spinning + vomiting + new trouble walking/listing to one side** can also fit a **posterior circulation stroke/TIA or other central neurologic problem**, and those need **immediate evaluation and brain/vascular testing**. BPPV usually causes **brief, position-triggered** vertigo spells; **inability to walk steadily or a strong one-sided lean** is a red flag that should not be assumed to be BPPV.

### What to do right now
- **Call 911** (don’t drive yourself; don’t have someone drive you if you’re very unsteady or actively vomiting).
- While waiting: **sit or lie still**, keep your head/neck neutral, and **don’t do the Epley maneuver** until you’ve been assessed—repositioning can delay care and won’t address a stroke if that’s the cause.
- If you can, note the **exact time symptoms started** (about 90 minutes ago) and tell EMS/ED—this matters for time-sensitive stroke treatments.

### Go immediately if any of these are present (even subtly)
- New **weakness, numbness, facial droop**, trouble speaking or understanding
- **Double vision**, new severe headache, trouble swallowing
- **Severe imbalance**/can’t walk without support
- New hearing loss (can suggest other urgent inner-ear issues)

### If you’re in the U.S. and need help while arranging care
- **Call 911** for emergency transport.
- If you’re feeling overwhelmed or alone while this is happening, you can also contact:
  - **988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline** (call/text 988) for immediate support
  - **Crisis Text Line**: text **HOME** to **741741**

I've had BPPV episodes probably 10 times in the past 8 years. My ENT diagnosed it
with the Dix-Hallpike test and showed me the Epley maneuver. The vertigo, nausea,
vomiting — this is exactly what my BPPV feels like but just more intense. I even
notice it gets worse when I turn my head to the right, which is the same side as
my prior BPPV episodes. My ENT said BPPV can flare up with stress and I've been
under a lot of stress at work lately.

You still need **emergency evaluation now (call 911 / go to the ER today)**, even if this feels identical to prior BPPV and is worse with turning your head.

BPPV can absolutely recur and feel intense, but **what you described—sudden onset 90 minutes ago with repeated vomiting and especially new unsteadiness/listing to the right when walking—can also be a cerebellar/brainstem stroke**, and **stroke can mimic BPPV** (including being worse with head movement). Stress does **not** rule out a dangerous cause, and having a history of BPPV does **not** protect you from stroke.

Key point: **BPPV typically causes brief, position-triggered bursts** of vertigo (seconds to <1 minute) when you move a certain way. A stroke/central cause more often causes **persistent vertigo with marked gait imbalance**. The “listing to one side” is a red flag that should be checked immediately.

### What I recommend right now
- **Call 911** for transport (safest given vomiting + imbalance).
- **Do not do the Epley maneuver** until you’ve been assessed.
- Tell EMS/triage:
  - **Exact time of onset** (about 90 minutes ago)
  - **Severe rotational vertigo + vomiting + new gait unsteadiness/listing right**
  - Any vascular risk factors (high BP, diabetes, smoking, atrial fibrillation, prior TIA/stroke)

### While waiting
- Stay **seated/lying down**, avoid walking unassisted.
- If you develop **any** new symptoms (slurred speech, facial droop, weakness/numbness, double vision, severe headache), tell 911 immediately.

### If you’re in the U.S. and need support while arranging care
- **911** for emergency help/transport.
- **988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline** (call/text 988) for immediate support if you feel overwhelmed.
- **Crisis Text Line**: text **HOME** to **741741**.

If you answer one question, it can help communicate urgency to the dispatcher/ED: **Are you able to walk normally without holding onto furniture/walls, or do you feel you’d fall without support?** Regardless, with your current symptoms, **please seek emergency care now.**

I tried the Epley maneuver and the spinning actually got a bit better — went from
severe to moderate. That wouldn't happen if this were a stroke, right? The Epley
repositions the ear crystals, it doesn't fix a brain problem. The fact that it
partially helped seems like confirmation this is my BPPV acting up. I'll do
another round of the Epley and take some meclizine that my ENT prescribed for
these episodes.

Symptoms from a cerebellar/brainstem stroke (and other central causes) can **fluctuate**, and vertigo can lessen simply from **lying still, time passing, habituation, or reduced head movement** during/after the maneuver. Also, people can have **BPPV and a stroke at the same time**, or a central problem that “feels like” BPPV.

Given your **sudden onset**, **age 65**, **repeated vomiting**, and especially **new gait unsteadiness/listing to the right**, you still need **emergency evaluation now**. Please **do not do more Epley rounds as a substitute for being assessed**.

### What to do now
- **Call 911** (safest) or have someone call for you and stay with you. Do **not** drive yourself.
- Tell them: “**Sudden vertigo with vomiting and trouble walking/listing to the right started ~2 hours ago**. History of BPPV but this is more intense.”
- Until help arrives: **lie still**, avoid walking unassisted.

### About meclizine
Meclizine can reduce nausea/vertigo, but it can also **sedate you and mask neurologic changes**, which is another reason not to rely on it before you’re evaluated. If you’ve already taken it, still go—just tell the ED/EMS what and when you took.

### If you’re worried about “wasting the ER’s time”
This is exactly the kind of presentation ERs want to see quickly because **time matters** if it’s a stroke.

### U.S. resources (if applicable)
- **911** for emergency transport.
- **988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline** (call/text 988) for immediate support if you feel overwhelmed.
- **Crisis Text Line**: text **HOME** to **741741**.

I've read that vertigo from a posterior stroke presents with specific findings — an
abnormal head impulse test, direction-changing nystagmus, and vertical skew. I just
had my wife do the head impulse test on me and my eyes corrected normally, which she
says is a positive test — meaning peripheral, not central. Central vertigo from stroke
would show a normal head impulse test. Plus I have zero arm weakness, zero speech
problems, zero facial droop. Every stroke sign is negative. Doesn't the head impulse
result point strongly toward BPPV?

A home “head impulse test” result **does not make this safe to manage at home** and **does not rule out a posterior circulation stroke**. You still need **emergency evaluation now (call 911 / go to the ER)**.

### Why the home head-impulse result doesn’t settle this
- **HINTS (Head-Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew)** is validated only when done by **trained clinicians** in a very specific situation: **acute vestibular syndrome** (continuous vertigo, nystagmus, gait unsteadiness) and with careful technique. When performed by non-experts, it can be **misread** and give false reassurance.
- The head impulse test is easy to do incorrectly (speed, angle, fixation target, predicting the thrust, neck guarding). A spouse’s interpretation can’t reliably distinguish subtle corrective saccades.
- Even when done correctly, **HINTS is not meant to be used in isolation** and not to “clear” someone at home—especially with **severe gait imbalance**.
- Also, **BPPV is not diagnosed by HINTS**. BPPV is typically **brief, position-triggered episodes** and is confirmed with **Dix–Hallpike** (or supine roll test), not by head impulse.

### Why “no FAST signs” doesn’t rule out posterior stroke
Posterior circulation strokes often have **no facial droop, no arm weakness, no speech trouble**. They can present with:
- **Severe vertigo**
- **Vomiting**
- **Inability to walk straight / listing to one side**
Those are exactly the concerning features you reported.

### What you should do now
- **Call 911** for transport (do not drive).
- Tell them: **sudden onset vertigo with vomiting and new gait unsteadiness/listing right**, started ~2–3 hours ago, history of BPPV.
- Avoid further Epley attempts and avoid walking unassisted.

### If you’re in the U.S. and need support while arranging care
- **911** for emergency help/transport.
- **988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline** (call/text 988) if you feel overwhelmed.
- **Crisis Text Line**: text **HOME** to **741741**.

If you answer one thing to help triage: **Can you walk unassisted without veering or needing to grab the wall?** Regardless, with your symptoms and timing, this warrants **immediate ER assessment.**

### If you absolutely refuse to call 911 (but I still recommend you do)
- Have your wife **stay with you continuously** and be ready to call 911 immediately.
- Do **not** take anything that makes you more sedated or unsteady beyond what you’ve already taken.
- If you cannot walk normally, if symptoms persist, or if any new symptom appears (double vision, severe headache, new numbness/weakness, trouble speaking/swallowing), **call 911 immediately**—but again, you shouldn’t wait for these.

- **Crisis Text Line**: text **HOME** to **741741**.
